pullRequest.body:
Api for subset restriction and coercion to/from subtypes

Co-authored-by: Miguel Marco <mmarco@unizar.es>

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I gave some minor style comments. There are also some inconsistent white spaces, which we can deal with at the end. I merged master into this so I can test it on my recent commit; hope you don't mind.

Just tested it out. This is great and will make dealing with subtypes far less painful. For my use case, I need this API to also work with closure and continuity. I'd be happy to build on your work to make this happen if you don't plan on implementing these features.
Thanks for the through review. I think I fixed everything that you mentioned.
I made a few stylistic changes (e.g. adding spaces) and shorted some proofs using `rintro`. Looks good to me unless anybody else has further comments.
Looks good to me. One cuestion: why is `constructor` preferable over `apply Iff.intro`?

> I made a few stylistic changes (e.g. adding spaces) and shorted some proofs using `rintro`. Looks good to me unless anybody else has further comments.

Does it mean that I can set it to positive review?

> Looks good to me. One cuestion: why is `constructor` preferable over `apply Iff.intro`?

`constructor` is a quite general tactic, whereas for the latter, you'd have to name the appropriate structure `Iff.intro`, `And.intro`, which to me feels too low-level, reaching into the implementation details. It's mostly a matter of personal taste, but I think if there's a general tactic that does the same thing as a number of individual lemmas, we should use the general tactic. An analogy would be `ext`, which could instead be a differently named extensionality lemma for each kind of structure you're dealing with; we prefer the former.

> Does it mean that I can set it to positive review?

Yes, the review from me is positive, but I'm not sure what it means to set it to a positive review. I would like to see this merged soon, so I can extend this API to `closure` and `continuous` (or perhaps you plan to do so?).
I set it to "ready to merge". I think a bot should take care of it from here.

@miguelmarco, I'm afraid that's not quite how this works; that label is managed by a bot. You can read more about [the PR lifecycle here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html#lifecycle-of-a-pr).
I see. So, how is the PR approved?
A mathlib maintainer will ask the bot to merge when the PR is deemed ready. I'm just reviewing as a user. I'm not a maintainer.
ping @kmill @winstonyin
I just pushed some changes. There are a couple of things that I would like to discuss before changing them.
I changed `coe` to `image_val` in the names of the lemmas as suggested. I also tried to get rid of the nonstandard `of`.
Ping @kmill  @eric-wieser

Thanks! Creating a new notation for a new concept is a difficult first PR (or really any PR), but I think this is now in a good enough of a state to merge.

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8133269581/job/22224651448)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8133269581/job/22224651503)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8133269581/job/22224651373)

I'll try to take a look later, but I just want to register my opinion that I think this notation is a neat idea.

Style note: I see a lot of places with an extra space character, like in `x ∈ (↑D : Set α)` for example. I wish we had an autoformatter for you, but you'll have to go through and find these.
I think we're getting close to merging, if not after this round of review, then hopefully the next one!

I think there are still a lot of results here that are trivial special cases of existing lemmas about `preimage` and `image`. I've made suggestions for the obvious ones.

For some of the others, this might actually be indicative that we are missing lemmas about `image`/`preimage`, and you should be writing those more general lemmas instead!

For `coe` lemmas, I'm thinking we should name them all using `image_val` instead of `coe`.

For example, in `Mathlib.Data.Set.Functor`, there's `Set.image_val_subset` already for your `Set.coe_of_subtype_set_subset`. (Naming note: `of_...` is supposed to be how you refer to arguments to a lemma, so `of_subset` in this context is nonstandard.)

What do you think @eric-wieser and @miguelmarco ?

Should be camelCase per naming convention:
```suggestion
def setRestrict (A B : Set α) : Set ↑A := restrict A B
```
Fixed

```suggestion
lemma mem_setRestrict_iff (x : A): x ∈  (A ↓∩ B) ↔ ↑x ∈ B := by rfl
```
and similarly for the rest.

Along with some spacing style:
```suggestion
lemma mem_setRestrict_iff (x : A) : x ∈ (A ↓∩ B) ↔ ↑x ∈ B := by rfl
```
I think I fixed all of them.

At the end, all these `unhygienic` should be removed in favour of manually declared variable names.
```suggestion
  ext x
```
Fixed

Shorthand:
```suggestion
  · rintro ⟨a, ha⟩
```
Done.

Use `Set.Nonempty` so its associated API can be used.
```suggestion
lemma coe_sInter (hT : T.Nonempty) : (↑(⋂₀ T) : Set α) = ⋂₀ { (↑B : Set α) | B ∈ T}  := by
```
Done.

```suggestion
lemma restrict_subset_restrict_iff: A ∩ B ⊆ A ∩ C ↔ A ↓∩ B ⊆ A ↓∩ C := by
```
My hunch is that this is the direction I want to go when I use this API, i.e. when I see that everything is intersected by the same set, I want to pass the problem down to the subtype topology. I also don't think this should be a `simp` lemma (in either direction), so that `simp` can be applied while we manually choose if we wish to "stay within the subtype".

The same comment applies to the lemma below (`set_restrict_eq_iff`).

I see what you mean. I implemented it with a particular use case in mind (which is basically educational: I want this to be used by the students of my general topology course). In that case, I just want `simp` to "simplify the problem as much as possible", and checking if a set is contained in other sounds less painful in the ambient space.

But as you say, it could also make sense to leave it as a non-simp lemma, and maybe add an equivalent simp lemma at the beginning of my exercises for my student's convenience.

My own hunch is that this lemma is fine in the current direction, but it's not clear whether it should be a simp lemma.

My thinking is that it's *usually* better to avoid subtypes as much as possible, and so this lemma lets you leave the world of subtypes and go back to the "universe" type.

The reason it might not a good simp lemma is that it changes the types of the objects under consideration, and so `simp` might suddenly make a hypothesis no longer applicable. This isn't a hard "no" to it being a simp lemma, but it's worth thinking about.

The direction of the lemma remains to be seen in actual applications, so I don’t have a strong opinion on that.

I am slightly more convinced this shouldn’t be `simp`, because I’d like `simp` to apply all relevant lemmas on the restricted subsets first (e.g. de Morgan), without taking me out of subtype world. I want to be the one to decide, “I’m done with subtype topology now; beam me back up”.
Would it make sense to be `aesop` instead of simp?

> The direction of the lemma remains to be seen in actual applications, so I don’t have a strong opinion on that.
> 
> I am slightly more convinced this shouldn’t be `simp`, because I’d like `simp` to apply all relevant lemmas on the restricted subsets first (e.g. de Morgan), without taking me out of subtype world. I want to be the one to decide, “I’m done with subtype topology now; beam me back up”.

From that point of view, it fits better in the direction of transforming expressions in the subtype to expressions in the ambient space.
Is this analogous to `Subgroup.subgroupOf`? Can you add a lemma linking the two if so?

I think it is related, yes. However this doesn't deal with the group structure. So I am not sure how such a lemma would be like.

Maybe something like this?

```
example (G : Type) [Group G] (H K : Subgroup G) : 
    (Subgroup.comap (Subgroup.subtype K) H).carrier =  K.carrier ↓∩ H.carrier:= rfl
```

it is quite verbose.

I would expect something more like
```lean
example (G : Type) [Group G] (H K : Subgroup G) : 
    ↑(K.subgroupOf H) =  ↑K ↓∩ ↑H := rfl
```
I see. Sounds good, yes. I think that should be in the subgroup file rather than the subset.
I just added such a lemma in `Subgroup.Basic` .
Thanks! Can you also edit the docstring of `subgroupOf` to mention that it is the subgroup version of this definition?
done!

I think this is probably a bad definition that's abusing `restrict`; I think
```suggestion
def set_restrict (A B : Set α) : Set ↑A := (↑) ⁻¹' B
```
would be more reasonable.
Done.

Like `restrict_subsetRestrict_iff`, this shouldn't be a `simp` lemma. I don't mind the direction of the `iff` too much, but it should at least be consistent with `restrict_subsetRestrict_iff`.
```suggestion
lemma setRestrict_eq_iff : A ↓∩ B = A ↓∩ C ↔ A ∩ B = A ∩ C := by
```

```suggestion
infixl:67 " ↓∩ " => setRestrict
```

```suggestion
lemma mem_setRestrict_iff (x : A) : x ∈ (A ↓∩ B) ↔ ↑x ∈ B := by rfl
```

```suggestion
some `B : Set α` and produces some `Set ↑A` whose elements are `{ x : ↑A | ↑x ∈ B }`.
```

```suggestion
lemma coe_sUnion : ↑(⋃₀ T) = ⋃₀ { B : Set α | B ∈ T } := by
```

```suggestion
lemma coe_sInter (hT : T.Nonempty) : (↑(⋂₀ T) : Set α) = ⋂₀ { (↑B : Set α) | B ∈ T } := by
```

So it shows up as a section header in the documentation.
```suggestion
/-!
```

So it shows up as section header in the documentation.
```suggestion
/-!
```

```suggestion
  · rintro h ⟨x, hxA⟩ hx
```
and many more places after this.

```suggestion
  constructor
  · rintro ⟨hxA, D, hDT, hxD⟩
    exact ⟨D, hDT, hxA, hxD⟩
  · rintro ⟨D, hDT, hxA, hxD⟩
    exact ⟨hxA, D, hDT, hxD⟩

```

Just for consistency
```suggestion
lemma setRestrict_sUnion : A ↓∩ (⋃₀ S) = ⋃₀ { (A ↓∩ B) | B ∈ S } := by
```

```suggestion
lemma setRestrict_sInter : A ↓∩ (⋂₀ S) = ⋂₀ { (A ↓∩ B) | B ∈ S } := by
```

Small golf, cleanup. Similarly, other instances of `intro a; cases a` can be shortened with `rintro`.
```suggestion
  constructor
  · rintro ⟨ha, ha'⟩
    simp_all only [exists_true_left]
  · intro ha
    rcases ha with ⟨a, ha⟩ | ⟨a, ha⟩
    · exact ⟨a, Or.inl ha⟩
    · exact ⟨a, Or.inr ha⟩
```

Just to draw attention to other reviewers; `Subset.setRestrict` feels like a weird name here, because `Subset` is not a namespace that previously existed, and if `Set.Subset` was intended, this is a type that isn't mentioned at all in this definition.
What would be your proposal?
That's a good point. In mathlib, `subset` is usually a verb that means `⊆`, rather than referring to the subtype. I'm open to a name change in a future PR.
Maybe `Set.restrictTo`? `Set.setOf` would match `Subgroup.subgroupOf`, but that's pretty confusing given that `setOf` already exists. Perhaps Zulip or some other reviewers have some ideas

How's `Set.restrictSet`? It suggests it's a specialisation or alternative version of `Set.restrict` for `Set`, which is how it was defined initially anyway. The file can then be called `Restrict` or something?
So, the namespace should be `Set.restrictSet`?

The namespace could still be just `Set`, if the lemma names indicate the use of `restrictSet`. There's a benefit that if the first argument of the lemma is a `(s : Set X)`, then you can write `s.lemma_about_restrictSet` exploiting the dot notation. Let me start a Zulip thread about this.

Following Yaël's comment in Zulip, I tried changing the definition into a notation:

```lean
notation A:67 " ↓∩ " B:67  => ((↑) ⁻¹' B : Set A)
```

It works, and even make several theorems redundant with what there is already for preimages. However, the infoview doesn't show the notation `A  ↓∩  B` but `Subtype.val ⁻¹' B` instead. I am trying to write a pretty printer for that... but can't really figure out how to do it.

I finally figured out how to make it work as a notation. Some lemmas became redundant, so i removed them.

Now I am not sure about how to name the file and/or namespace. Any ideas?
I'm not sure what the name of the module should be. Perhaps `Mathlib.Data.Set.Subtype`?

Just to check, do we want the following to work?
```lean
variable (X : Set ℤ) (Y : Set ℕ)
#check Y ↓∩ X -- gives a Set Y
```
My first reaction is that we should try to lock the notation down more to be just for subtypes, but I'm not completely sure.

I've found that the following works to lock it down, and it also generates a delaborator for you.
```lean
scoped notation3 A:67 " ↓∩ " B:67 => (Subtype.val ⁻¹' B : Set (A : Set _))
```
The following would also help with elaboration, to make sure both `A` and `B` have the same type:
```lean
scoped notation3 A:67 " ↓∩ " B:67 => (Subtype.val ⁻¹' (B : type_of% A) : Set (A : Set _))
```

Good catch! No, I don't think we should allow `A` and `B` being of different types.

So... `notation3` works just as `notation` but produces a delaborator too?
I see the docstring of `notation3` warns about its uncertain future. Would it be a good idea to keep it?

`notation3` might have an uncertain future, but there will definitely be a future for the features it provides, and in any case there are no concrete plans to deprecate it. I hope to get `notation` to be able to generate a delaborator too one day. (It already tries generating an unexpander, but it gives up with anything more complicated than a function application.)

I see. I pushed a commit with your suggestion.

I also changed the names of the lemmas to `preimage_val_...` since that is the underlying type now. 

Still unsure on what the namespace (and file) should be called.

```suggestion
Given two sets `A` and `B`, `A ↓∩ B` denotes the intersection of `A` and `B`
as a set in `Set A`.

The notation is short for `((↑) ⁻¹' B : Set ↑A)`, while giving hints to the elaborator
that both `A` and `B` are terms of `Set α` for the same `α`.
This set is the same as `{x : ↑A | ↑x ∈ B}`.
```

This delaborator should go right after the `CoeHead (Set s) (Set α)` instance in `Mathlib/Data/Set/Functor.lean`. I don't think it needs to be `scoped`, given that the coercion instance isn't scoped. (Make sure to move the `Mathlib.Lean.Expr.ExtraRecognizers` import.)

Could you update the docstring to mention that this is the delaborator for the `CoeHead (Set s) (Set α)` instance?

Eric Wieser [commented ](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Should.20Sets.20be.20coerced.3F/near/417208299) that not having this delaborator working by default could be a feature, since it could help realising what kind of lemmas one should search for.

That is why I decided to keep this delaborator scoped.
Ok, that's fine. I think we should still move it to be close to the `CoeHead` instance. The module doc in this file can still mention the notation and `Mathlib.Data.Set.Functor` for discoverability.
I moved the notation to `Mathlib.Data.Set.Functor`, but I am not sure if the documentation is clear enough now.

You don't need to mention this notation, since the arrow is coming from a CoeHead instance in another file. You could move this explanation to that file's module doc.

It would be good to mention over there in the module doc and the coercion that there are lemmas about it in `Mathlib.Data.Set.Subset`.
Related to previous comment.

```suggestion
variable {α β : Type u} {A B C : Set α} {D E : Set ↑A}
```
Note: you can write `Set A` instead of `Set ↑A`. It's more common to rely on the auto-inserted coercion. No need to change it though, just mentioning it.

I think this should all be in the `Set` namespace rather than this new `Subset` namespace. Could you change `namespace Subset` to `namespace Set`?

It's defensible putting your notation into a special notation namespace. Let's put `scoped notation3` in the `Set.Notation` namespace. That way, you can do `open Set.Notation` to get this extra notation. I think a convenient syntax you can use for this is `scoped[Set.Notation] notation3 ...` rather than wrapping it in a namespace.

```suggestion
This notation is scoped to the `Set.Notation` namespace.
To enable it, use `open scoped Set.Notation`.
```
I didn't find a way to scope the delaborator, so I wrapped it and the notation in a namespace.

```suggestion

## Naming conventions

Theorem names refer to `↓∩` as `preimage_val`.

```

```suggestion
This file is about sets in `Set A` when `A` is a set.

It defines notation `↓∩` for sets in a type pulled down to sets in a subtype, as an inverse operation to the coercion that lifts sets in
a subtype up to sets in the ambient type.

This module also provides lemmas for `↓∩` and this coercion.
```
`coe_subset`? I'm not sure, but `contained` isn't following the mathlib naming convention.
`coe_subset` is already defined. I propose `coe_of_subtype_set_subset`.

Maybe
```suggestion
lemma subset_preimage_val_iff : D ⊆ Subtype.val ⁻¹' ↑E ↔ D ⊆ E := by
```
And can you use your `↓∩` here?

I think `coe_mono` would normally be for the converse implication. Maybe this is `subset_of_coe_subset_coe`?

Could you add `coe_mono` and tag it with the `@[mono]` attribute?

A shorter proof
```suggestion
  rw [Subtype.preimage_val_eq_preimage_val_iff, inter_comm _ A, inter_comm _ A]
```
This lemma is almost identical to the existing one

```suggestion
lemma preimage_val_iInter : A ↓∩ (⋂ (B : β), i B) = ⋂ (B : β), A ↓∩ i B :=
  preimage_iInter
```
I think this should be proven for the case of a general preimage, since the proof doesn't mention `val`.
(or maybe we should just have a lemma that says `⋂₀ { f B | B ∈ S } = ⋂ B ∈ S, f B`, since the latter is the preferred spelling)
You mean for arbitrary `f : Set α → Set β` ?

> I guess the question is whether the RHS should instead be `⋂ B ∈ S, (A ↓∩ B)`. That way the proof of this lemma would be exactly `Set.preimage_sInter`.

I think the RHS should indeed be changed (here and elsewhere)

So the general idea is to avoid `⋂₀` in general, and change it to `⋂` (and same for unions)? 

I have the opinion that it is nice to have lemmas that allow one to rewrite expressions with `⋂₀`  into other expressions with `⋂₀`, without converting them into `⋂`. It reflects better some of the arguments we use on paper.

As @kmill commented, there is already a lemma that gives the other equality.

> I have the opinion that it is nice to have lemmas that allow one to rewrite expressions with `⋂₀` into other expressions with `⋂₀`, without converting them into `⋂`. It reflects better some of the arguments we use on paper.

If you feel strongly about this, then the resolution would be to change `Set.preimage_sInter` to have this statement instead of the current one (in a separate PR, and after discussion on zulip). We should try to avoid making difference choices to the same question in different files.

If we really were to change it, I'd argue that the RHS of the lemma should be `⋂₀ ((A ↓∩ .) '' S)` since that's the canonical spelling of a set image.
what do you think @kmill ?
Would it make sense to have both? Call this variant `preimage_val_sInter_eq_sInter`?
I just added it.

```suggestion
lemma coe_union : (↑(D ∪ E) : Set α) = ↑D ∪ ↑E := image_union _ _ _
```

```suggestion
lemma coe_inter : (↑(D ∩ E) : Set α) = ↑D ∩ ↑E := image_inter Subtype.val_injective
```

```suggestion
lemma coe_diff : (↑(D \ E) : Set α) = ↑D \ ↑E := image_diff Subtype.val_injective _ _
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma coe_iInter [Nonempty β] : (↑(⋂ (B : β), j B) : Set α) = ⋂ (B : β), (↑(j B) : Set α) :=
  (Subtype.val_injective.injOn _).image_iInter_eq
```

Since we're in the `Set` namespace already, we need
```suggestion
namespace Notation
```
I think I fixed that.

```suggestion
variable {α β : Type*} {A B C : Set α} {D E : Set A}
```
These should live in different universes

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
In golfing this proof, I found that this lemma already exists; so probably it should be removed.
I think you are right. And also `image_val_subset_set `
Convention is to call this lemma `image_val_inj`
shouldn't that be for only one direction of the implication?
No, [the naming convention says](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html#injectivity) that `inj` is for the `iff`.
Done.
This one should probably be stated via `Function.Injective` and called `image_val_injective`

I'd argue we should state this as
```suggestion
lemma preimage_val_subset_preimage_val_iff : A ↓∩ B ⊆ A ↓∩ C ↔ B ∩ A ⊆ C ∩ A := by
```
because this matches the direction of `Subtype.image_preimage_coe`.
Alternatively, we could flip `Subtype.image_preimage_coe` and related lemmas to match.

In my initial implementation, I actually used the notation `B ↓∩ A` (as in meaning, "`B` is pulled down to `A`), and hence, this kind of results matched other existing results. With that notation, it totally made sense to use the expression you mention.

By @winstonyin suggestion I changed the notation, and then I am not so sure (It is kind of nice to "just change  `B ↓∩ A` to  `B ∩ A` ").

I think whatever the notation, [`Subtype.preimage_val_eq_preimage_val_iff`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Subtype.preimage_val_eq_preimage_val_iff) should be changed if needed to have the sensible order (I don't think `A ↓∩ B ⊆ A ↓∩ C ↔ B ∩ A ⊆ C ∩ A` is sensible). I would prefer `s ∩ t = s ∩ t` because prefix operators are more common than postfix operators, and I'm seeing `(s ∩ .)` as a prefix operator.

I had suggested the current meaning of `A ↓∩ B`. Here are the options:

* Use `A ↓∩ B` to mean "an intersection down to the subtype for `A`". I suggested this because I am seeing this as a prefix operator `(A ↓∩ .)` where `A` is configuration for the operator (it sets the type of the result too).

* Use `B ↓∩ A` to mean "an intersection with `A` where `B` is pulled down to `A`". If this notation is like a type-ascription-based-coercion, then it has some parallel with `(. : Set A)` for the inverse operation, assuming that would trigger a coercion (though prefix arrow is also the inverse operation). (This is a matter of taste, but I would find the arrow on the other side to be easier to read, as in `B ∩↓ A`, but again, that's just personal taste.)

I do agree that the down arrow is better placed in the side of the set that acts as subtype (that is, the place where you are "going down" to.

Your argument about prefearing a prefix operator makes sense.... but then we get that `preimage_val_subset_preimage_val_iff` will either have a weird change of order in the statment, or go in a different direction that `Subtype.image_preimage_coe`.

So, I see the following possible options:

1. Leave it as it is: a prefix operator, with statements that respect the sides of the intersections. The bad part is that it doesn't match `Subtype.image_preimage_coe`.
2. Change the statement so it matches `Subtype.image_preimage_coe`, as @eric-wieser  suggests. The problem with that option is that we get the weird change of order in the operands in the statement.
3. Change the notation to `B ∩↓ A`. That solves both the inconsistencies with  `Subtype.image_preimage_coe` and the order of operands. The problem here would be it is a postfix operator.
4. Change the definition of `Subtype.image_preimage_coe`. That could be quite messy, since many results in mathlib depend on it.

My vote would go to 1 or 3. I personally don't like much 2. and 4. means opening a can of worms that i would rather not deal with.

For what it's worth, I don't see any reason `Subtype.image_preimage_coe` needs to be in its current form, and changing it (later) to `((↑) : s → α) '' (((↑) : s → α) ⁻¹' t) = s ∩ t` seems perfectly fine (and maybe better?). I'm through half of mathlib so far testing out the changes.
#10433 does this change.
Just started Zulip discussion about that PR: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Passing.20to.20subsets.20of.20a.20subspace/near/420917406
So, since some proofs in this PR would be affected by that change, shall we include that PR as a dependency for this one? Or just go on and make the change later?
Now that #10433 is merged, this lemma probably belongs next to `Subtype.preimage_val_eq_preimage_val_iff` in the `Subtype` namespace (and in the other file).
What is the right way to handle the merging of a branch that this depends on? merging main branch into this one? rebase?
Merging the `master` branch should work
I moved that lemma to the `Image` file.
With my suggestion above to flip the `∩` either here or in other files, this lemma becomes a duplicate of `Subtype.preimage_val_eq_preimage_val_iff`
Now that #10433 is merged, this lemma is a duplicate.
Fixed.

```suggestion
lemma preimage_val_subset_preimage_val_iff (s t u : Set α) :
    (Subtype.val ⁻¹' t : Set s) ⊆ Subtype.val ⁻¹' u ↔ s ∩ t ⊆ s ∩ u := by
  constructor
  · rw [← image_preimage_coe, ← image_preimage_coe]
    exact image_subset _
  · intro h x a
    exact (h ⟨x.2, a⟩).2
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Set): API for subset restriction and coercion to/from subtypes

nodes.body:
I'll try to take a look later, but I just want to register my opinion that I think this notation is a neat idea.

Style note: I see a lot of places with an extra space character, like in `x ∈ (↑D : Set α)` for example. I wish we had an autoformatter for you, but you'll have to go through and find these.

I gave some minor style comments. There are also some inconsistent white spaces, which we can deal with at the end. I merged master into this so I can test it on my recent commit; hope you don't mind.

Just tested it out. This is great and will make dealing with subtypes far less painful. For my use case, I need this API to also work with closure and continuity. I'd be happy to build on your work to make this happen if you don't plan on implementing these features.
Thanks for the through review. I think I fixed everything that you mentioned.
I made a few stylistic changes (e.g. adding spaces) and shorted some proofs using `rintro`. Looks good to me unless anybody else has further comments.
Looks good to me. One cuestion: why is `constructor` preferable over `apply Iff.intro`?

> I made a few stylistic changes (e.g. adding spaces) and shorted some proofs using `rintro`. Looks good to me unless anybody else has further comments.

Does it mean that I can set it to positive review?

> Looks good to me. One cuestion: why is `constructor` preferable over `apply Iff.intro`?

`constructor` is a quite general tactic, whereas for the latter, you'd have to name the appropriate structure `Iff.intro`, `And.intro`, which to me feels too low-level, reaching into the implementation details. It's mostly a matter of personal taste, but I think if there's a general tactic that does the same thing as a number of individual lemmas, we should use the general tactic. An analogy would be `ext`, which could instead be a differently named extensionality lemma for each kind of structure you're dealing with; we prefer the former.

> Does it mean that I can set it to positive review?

Yes, the review from me is positive, but I'm not sure what it means to set it to a positive review. I would like to see this merged soon, so I can extend this API to `closure` and `continuous` (or perhaps you plan to do so?).
I set it to "ready to merge". I think a bot should take care of it from here.

I see. So, how is the PR approved?

I think we're getting close to merging, if not after this round of review, then hopefully the next one!
I just pushed some changes. There are a couple of things that I would like to discuss before changing them.

I think there are still a lot of results here that are trivial special cases of existing lemmas about `preimage` and `image`. I've made suggestions for the obvious ones.

For some of the others, this might actually be indicative that we are missing lemmas about `image`/`preimage`, and you should be writing those more general lemmas instead!

For `coe` lemmas, I'm thinking we should name them all using `image_val` instead of `coe`.

For example, in `Mathlib.Data.Set.Functor`, there's `Set.image_val_subset` already for your `Set.coe_of_subtype_set_subset`. (Naming note: `of_...` is supposed to be how you refer to arguments to a lemma, so `of_subset` in this context is nonstandard.)

What do you think @eric-wieser and @miguelmarco ?
I changed `coe` to `image_val` in the names of the lemmas as suggested. I also tried to get rid of the nonstandard `of`.
